awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Scalable Combinatorial Scientific Computing
PI: Umit V. Catalyurek

Abstract:

Combinatorial algorithms are an important enabling technology for scientific computing, especially for large-scale problems and high performance computing. The overarching goals of this project are development of 1) a mathematical and computational infrastructure for solving graph and hypergraph-based combinatorial problems on extreme-scale architectures and 2) techniques and tools for analysis of complex and multivalent interaction networks.

In this project, effective novel combinatorial models, such as hypergraph, k-partite hypergraph and directed hypergraph models, are developed for modeling complex workflows (computation, communication and data dependencies, and data access patterns) of large-scale scientific applications and the complicated interactions of chemical and biological entities. New scalable algorithms, based on a multi-level framework, are designed for graph and hypergraph clustering and partitioning, and dynamic load balancing problems. Scalable graph coloring techniques and graph search-based analysis techniques for semantic graphs are developed on top of an extensible distributed memory graph/hypergraph runtime middleware.

The technical impact of this work will be in designing efficient models and algorithms for the above mentioned computationally challenging problems. Hence, in many fields of science the work will allow the use of parallel computing where it was not possible before. The education and outreach activities of this project include a summer program for high school students from underrepresented groups, significant expansion of graduate courses, undergraduate student involvement in research projects, and graduate student education through multi-disciplinary projects. The implementations of the novel models and algorithms developed in the project will be distributed as open source to maximize the impact and dissemination of the research results.

In computational sciences, graphs are one of the most widely used mathematical abstractions to model various real world phenomena, including the computational structure of sequential and parallel programs. Graphs are useful in representing binary interactions, such as a road connecting two cities, or a friendship connecting two people. However, they are inadequate when it comes to representing multi-way relationships, such as single highway connecting multiple cities, or groups of friends. This is where hypergraphs come in handy. In a hypergraph, a hyperedge can represent groups of entities that are related. Hence, hypergraphs are much more versatile to model complex relationships. In this project, we enhanced existing hypergraph models to express the complex relationships that occur in computational sciences and biological networks, and developed sequential and parallel algorithms for solving various problems modeled as graphs and hypergraphs.

The intellectual merits of this project lie at the intersection of design and development of new models for various complex problems, as well as the development of efficient algorithms. Some of the problems, especially the ones from computational sciences, involve very large problems which can only be solved by using parallel processing. However, due to the sequential nature and/or irregular computational dependencies in these graph/hypergraph-based solutions, they are extremely difficult to parallelize. We have developed various scalable graph/hypergraph algorithms, including hypergraph partitioning tools and graph coloring techniques that scale on modern parallel architectures with thousands of processors. We have also developed several sequential algorithms for solving various combinatorial problems including matrix partitioning, scheduling, and clustering.

The techniques developed in this project can be used in various application domains including engineering and computational sciences as well as biological sciences. For example, the bi-clustering algorithm that we developed helped to identify new biomarker genes for breast cancer. Many of these techniques have been implemented and the tools have been made publically available to increase knowledge dissemination. Some of these tools have already been used by a wider research community and have hence made an impact on various application domains.

The results and findings of our research have been extensively published in numerous high profile scientific venues, including prestigious conference proceedings and journals. In addition, we organized mini-symposiums (at SIAM CSE’09, SIAM PP’10, SIAM PP’12) and workshops (ParGraph at HiPC’2011 and HiPC’2012) targeted to various research communities to further disseminate our findings, as well as bring researchers with similar interests together. 

This project made a significant contribution to training next generation researchers as well as attracting high-school students to computer science. We organized a successful two-week summer program for high-school students from underrepresented groups.
